report_title: HVAC Service Franchises in the US
executive_summary: HVAC franchises install, repair and run maintenance for heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) and refrigeration systems. Demand for HVAC franchises is derived from two main downstream markets, the residential and nonresidential markets. Through the end of 2023, the residential market has experienced booming growth as low interest rates and COVID-19 influenced high demand for new housing and investment in existing housing. HVAC installation, repair and maintenance is required at all these junctures, boosting demand for HVAC franchises. The second market is nonresidential; this market faced severe conditions through COVID-19 since most businesses had to close to stop the spread of the virus.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: HVAC service franchise revenue has fallen at a CAGR of 0.2% to $1.1 billion through the end of 2023, including a 6.1% increase in 2023, when profit reaches 4.5%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Residential Sector Provided a Massive Boost for HVAC Services
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With heightened demand for new housing throughout the period, HVAC franchises experienced greater demand for new unit installation and maintenance. Greater demand buoyed HVAC franchises through COVID as other downstream markets faltered.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Interest Rates Affected Demand for Both Major Downstream Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes in 2022, consumers and businesses had to change their spending habits. This meant businesses were less likely to expand operations, and consumers were less likely to buy a house. With heightened rates, the cost of borrowing to finance a new house or office building increased significantly. Shying away from both markets, in turn, depresses demand for HVAC services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 CAUSES DISRUPTIONS IN MOST MARKETS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic caused many stores and factories to close shop, resulting in less spending from consumers on nonessential goods and services. Revenue for many businesses and corporations proceeded to plummet, which severely reduced spending on constructing office buildings and other nonresidential structures, causing demand for HVAC franchises to decline precipitously. COVID-19 also encouraged consumers to spend less on items such as refrigerators, which led to less contracting work to install these devices. The recovery led to a resurgence in these markets, but the nonresidential sector remains muted.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ELEVATED INTEREST RATES WILL DEPRESS THE RESIDENTIAL SECTOR
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To fight the persistent inflation in the US economy, the Federal Reserve plans to keep the benchmark interest rates higher during the first half of the outlook period. High interest rates affect consumers' ability to purchase a home, often driving them away from financing one. With less homebuyers in the market, HVAC installation in the residential sector will drop.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A GROWING BUSINESS SECTOR WILL AID HVAC FRANCHISES AS OTHER MARKETS FALTER
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Albeit marginal, the nonresidential sector will rise through the end of 2028. This will give HVAC franchises a dim outlook as the rest of the markets flail through high interest rates. High interest rates will still be an issue for corporate clients because financing large expansions, such as plants, warehouses and offices, will still be expensive.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: E N V I R O N M E N T A L LY  F R I E N D LY  S Y S T E M S  A R E  T H E  W A Y  O F  T H E F U T U R E
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To adhere to shifting consumer preferences and new government regulations, manufacturers of HVAC units have had to invest heavily in new technology. Refrigerant hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) must be phased out of manufacturing by 2030, since it is proven to break down the ozone layer, causing permanent damage to the climate. New systems will be needed due to this, giving HVAC franchises a massive downstream market moving forward. The government is also giving tax advantages to consumers and businesses that switch, speeding up this process.

industry_definition: This industry operates franchised businesses that provide heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) services to residential and commercial customers. IBISWorld's Business Franchise collection focuses solely on the operation of franchised outlets and exclude nonfranchise data. These reports show the total number of franchise outlets, total franchise revenue and the average profit margin earned by franchisees. They also highlight the largest franchisors by market share.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level medium - steady

key_trends: HVAC franchises experienced greater demand for new unit installation and maintenance during COVID
High interest rates have hurt demand from consumers and businesses
COVID-19 encouraged consumers to spend less on items such as refrigerators
HVAC installation in the residential sector will drop with fewer homebuyers in the market
High interest rates will still be an issue for corporate clients
Manufacturers of HVAC units have had to invest heavily in new technology

market_segmentation.segment: Healthcare, public safety and educational buildings
market_segmentation.segment_description: New manufacturing plants and industrial buildings are constructed when the need for finished products is high, so the strength of this segment mostly

Spending at HVAC franchises by residential markets is determined by whether households are spending on new homes and home improvements. Demand from this segment has been very strong, as massive aid from the federal government and record low-interest rates amid COVID-19 spurred spending on new homes, so spending on HVAC contractors from residencies was similarly elevated. The market faces severe threats from rising interest rates, as the Federal Reserve has been putting upward pressure on them to reduce inflation.
Downstream Demand from the Manufacturing Sector Influences HVAC Spending on Industrial Buildings

The onset of COVID-19 shuttered many offices, as it was safer for employees to do their work virtually if they could. Since working from home had a major appeal, office capacity is still lower than before the pandemic. To save money, major companies will sell their office space, reducing the need for HVAC installation in office buildings.

Private nonresidential construction is the main driver for HVAC installations on commercial buildings. More nonresidential construction means demand for air-conditioning and heating contractors is higher. The value of nonresidential construction has lagged in recent years, as COVID-19, high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears have discouraged companies from spending on big projects, which has reduced the need for HVAC installations in commercial buildings.

Fewer college students threaten HVAC franchises that work on educational facilities. More college students cause universities to build more dorm rooms, libraries and classrooms, so spending on HVAC installations in these facilities will rise in tandem. As the large millennial generation has largely graduated college, the number of college students has fallen, threatening this market.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The Need for New HVAC Installations Follows Trends in the Housing Market
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The structures that often need new HVAC installations are new homes, so housing starts and the value of residential construction have the most influence on this segment. Spending on new installations has risen substantially, as low-interest rates and massive government aid encouraged homebuying during COVID-19. Demand for new HVAC installations has fallen as an aggressive Federal Reserve has increased rates to combat inflation.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Investment in Nonresidential Structures Influences Demand for Existing HVAC Installations
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Construction on existing HVAC systems often occurs in nonresidential buildings, as they are more likely to require a different structure tailored to the specific service being sold there. The value of nonresidential construction declined significantly during the pandemic amid vast business closures and mass social distancing, causing spending on existing HVAC installations to fall quickly. This trend continued in 2022, as high inflation and rising interest rates caused spending on nonresidential construction to fall. The segment will grow moving forward because of lower inflation and steady economic growth.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Maintenance of HVAC systems is viewed as a necessity regardless of economic conditions
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Maintenance of HVAC systems occurs when existing installations must be repaired. Households need heating and air-conditioning to work in a safe and comfortable environment, so they usually spend money on these repairs regardless of economic conditions. Some consumers may upgrade their HVAC systems during periods of high disposable income, so higher private spending on home improvements can indicate a higher incidence of HVAC system maintenance.

Most refrigeration services are purchased by restaurants, catering halls, hospitals and other businesses that need to keep their products cool. Given modern concerns regarding climate change, consumers are worried about chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) emissions into the atmosphere, often from fridges. Refrigerator manufacturers have been building new structures that reduce emissions and can be powered by renewable energy more effectively, leading contractors to increasingly gain expertise in installing these new systems.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region houses some of the most populous states in the United States, namely Florida, Georgia and North Carolina. This region is also in a very warm climate, requiring more HVAC services more frequently during the year.

business_locations.location: The Great Lakes, Which Has a Big Industrial Sector
business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region is home to cities such as Chicago, Detroit and Cleveland, which each have major manufacturing industries. These companies consistently buy or renovate buildings, so demand for new and existing HVAC installations is high in this region. These states are also very cold during winter months, so high spending on heating requires many heating and air-conditioning contractors.

business_locations.location: West Offers the Best of Both Worlds
business_locations.location_description: Touting both a large population and bustling tech and business hubs, this region offers two major markets.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Heating and air-conditioning contractors are subject to regulations in many states that require them to go through extensive education and training to become HVAC technicians.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) of 1980
regulations_points.regulation_description: CERCLA permits the federal government to tax or charge companies that emit hazardous materials.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Title VI of the Clean Air Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: This amendment to the Clean Air Act of 1990 regulates the number of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) in the atmosphere.
The EPA regulates how efficient air-conditioning and heating systems should be in a certain region.
Contractors must follow standards set by the Air Conditioning, Heating and Refrigeration Institute (AHRI), which is accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).
During COVID-19, state governments required that businesses engage in social distancing and that their employees start wearing masks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry assistance level is low and steady.
The competition level is high and increasing.
New entrants must be amendable to different state and local regulations, which limit state-to-state operations.
Start-up costs for HVAC services are significant, often costing new entrants between $77,000 and $550,000.
Low start-up costs and the similarity of products lead to numerous companies, so competition is high within regions among contractors.

basis_points.basis_description: Franchises in the HVAC Service Franchises industry compete primarily on price, the variety of services offered and reputation. Throughout the industry, operators generate business through referrals, which most often stem from previous repair and installation jobs or ongoing maintenance contracts with manufacturers, retailers and building developers.

In addition to other franchise establishments, franchisees must compete with nonfranchise operators. Industry franchises also experience competition from external sources, namely construction companies.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Franchises Scale Easily, Leading to Wide-reaching, Hyper Concentrated Players
concentration_points.concentration_description: Franchises make opening a location very easy. Offering two options for franchising, owners can open from scratch or convert an already existing HVAC company for relatively low costs. Large franchises can take advantage of their size, leading to increased concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Consolidation Differs by the Type of Businesses Served
concentration_points.concentration_description: HVAC franchises must employ different practices when installing their systems in different buildings, as commercial and industrial systems require significantly more investment upfront. The increased complexity of nonresidential HVAC systems encourages larger companies to have greater influence in this market since they can afford the big upfront investment. Residential systems are more simplistic, so localized franchises tend to dominate.

top_companies.company_name: ONE HOUR HEATING & AIR CONDITIONING SUB-BRANDS: MISTER SPARKY, MONSTER TREE SERVICE, BENJAMIN FRANKLIN THE PUNCTUAL PLUMBER, SERVICE TEAM OF PROFESSIONAL, HOMEWATCH CAREGIVERS, MOSQUITO SQUAD, WOOFIE'S, THE CLEANING AUTHORITY, DOODYCALLS, COLOR WORLD HOUSEPAINTING, ASP

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Global supply issues keep purchase costs high
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Global trade issue have significantly raised the price of inputs for HVAC installation, repair and maintenance franchises.
Installation, maintenance and repair of HVAC units requires a great deal of technical and mechanical knowledge.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The HVAC Service Franchises industry has a low level of capital intensity; HVAC installation, repair and maintenance services rely primarily on labor.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital costs vary for each franchise location
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital costs vary for each location and each franchisee, with most franchisors offering training and support.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Interest rates can make or break industry performance
volatility_points.volatility_description: HVAC franchises' largest downstream market is the housing market. Housing demand is dependent on economy-wide interest rates, due to mortgage rates being pinned to the Federal Funds rate.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Needed maintenance keeps HVAC franchises relevant regardless of market conditions
volatility_points.volatility_description: HVAC systems need regular maintenance to ensure they are running properly. Maintenance services must always have a consistent level of demand, despite economic conditions outside of the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Expansion into the nonresidential sector helps shield franchises from some volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Having only one downstream market can be great when the economy is strong, but can bring unwanted volatility in poor economic conditions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The HVAC Service Franchises industry is not subject to any serious technological disruption.

The HVAC Service Franchises industry has a medium level of technology change. Technological change largely occurs at the manufacturing level, with contractors' techniques and knowledge then catching up to handle new developments.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or nonresidential construction markets? Can you easily switch between these markets?
FAQs.answer: HVAC Service Franchises industry operators work with both residential and nonresidential construction markets.

FAQs.question: Are you solely focused on new work, or do you participate in remodeling activities?
FAQs.answer: HVAC Service Franchises industry operators perform new installations and repairs depending on the customer.

FAQs.question: Does your company make use of subcontractors to save on wage costs? Roughly, what percent of revenue is consumed by wages?
FAQs.answer: Operators use subcontractors to cut back on wage costs. Roughly 20.0% to 25.0% of industry revenue is consumed by wages.

FAQs.question: What is the size of your staff? How does that compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Operators have relatively small staffs, typically ranging from three to 15 employees.

FAQs.question: In light of increasing wage costs, has your company considered using new technologies to increase productivity or reduce total employment?
FAQs.answer: Automation in this industry is low and HVAC Service Franchises industry operators must employ highly skilled workers that cannot be currently replaced.

FAQs.question: Have productivity issues ever kept you from winning lucrative contracts over larger competitors?
FAQs.answer: Operators that are most efficient typically win lucrative contracts, which places an emphasis on the competency of industry employees.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met on and off the construction site?
FAQs.answer: Operators follow federal and state guidelines to ensure that safety requirements are met for employees.

FAQs.question: Do you work with local or national trade associations to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators benefits from industry associations such as the Air-Conditioning, Heating and Refrigeration Institute.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Industry profit typically ranges from 2.0% of industry revenue to 7.0%.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: The biggest financing challenge that HVAC Service Franchises industry operators face include purchase costs, which fluctuates based on volatile commodity prices.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: Franchises need to establish a reputation for quality, value and punctuality with their target markets. Establishing a good reputation is critical given the fragmented nature of this industry, with a large number of small operators serving local markets.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology? What are the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: Industry franchises must keep up with the latest technological advancements in HVAC systems, as newer, more energy-efficient units might require different tools and procedures for installation and repairs.

FAQs.question: How do you manage input costs? Do you have deals in place based on economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: Industry franchises must manage a steady workflow, despite wide cyclical fluctuations in demand that occur during the summer and winter months. In addition, operators must adapt and plan their work in accordance with construction cycles.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue depends on demand from regular consumers? What are some other ways to boost demand?
FAQs.answer: Since heating and air conditioning are typically considered essential to a household's quality of life, the maintenance of working HVAC systems is more resistant to economic downturns than other types of home improvement activities.

FAQs.question: How much do you serve the nonresidential construction market? How can you make further inroads in this growing segment?
FAQs.answer: The industry derives a large share of its revenue from installing, maintaining and repairing air-conditioning, climate control and refrigeration systems in these buildings. The industry benefits from increases in private investments into nonresidential structures.

FAQs.question: How does a rise in disposable income levels benefit your industry? How do you take advantage of this opportunity?
FAQs.answer: The industry benefits from increases in per capita disposable income because consumers have more income to spend on housing renovations and additions.
